"The Steerage" is a photograph taken by Alfred Stieglitz in 1907. It is considered one of his most famous and influential works, and is widely regarded as a masterpiece of modernist photography.

The photograph was taken on board the S.S. Kaiser Wilhelm II, a passenger ship that was traveling from New York to Bremen, Germany. Stieglitz was on board the ship with his wife and child, and he was struck by the stark contrast between the first-class passengers, who were traveling in luxury and comfort, and the steerage passengers, who were traveling in cramped and difficult conditions.

"The Steerage" shows a group of steerage passengers gathered on the deck of the ship. The photograph is divided into two distinct areas: the upper half of the image is filled with a grid-like pattern of ropes and rigging, while the lower half shows the passengers, who are arranged in a series of geometric shapes and patterns.

Stieglitz used a variety of photographic techniques to create the complex and nuanced texture of the photograph. He used a large-format camera and a long exposure time to capture the intricate details of the scene, and used careful darkroom manipulation to achieve a wide range of tones and textures.

"The Steerage" is often seen as a commentary on the social and economic disparities of the time, and has been interpreted as a symbol of the fragmentation and isolation of modern life. It is also seen as a seminal work in the development of modernist photography, and has influenced generations of photographers who have sought to capture the complexity and depth of the human experience.
